title: Action-reaction pair for cart on hill

content.description: A cart of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is approaching a hill with a circular top of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure above. The cart is carrying a load also of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is traveling with speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> when it is at the top of the hill. The length of the cart is negligible in comparison to the radius of the hill. The cart never loses contact with the hill’s surface. The cart and load can both be considered to be at the same position.
content.question: Which of the following claims identifies an action-reaction pair of forces due to Newton’s third law and provides appropriate reasoning to justify this claim?

choices.label: The normal force exerted on the load by the cart and the gravitational force exerted on the load by Earth, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on the same object.
The normal force exerted on the load by the cart and the gravitational force exerted on the load by Earth, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on different objects.
The normal force exerted on the load by the cart and the normal force exerted on the cart by the load, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on the same object.
The normal force exerted on the load by the cart and the normal force exerted on the cart by the load, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on different objects.
The gravitational force exerted on the cart by Earth and the normal force exerted by the hill on the cart, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on different objects.

content.answer: The normal force exerted on the load by the cart and the normal force exerted on the cart by the load, because these are equal and opposite forces that act on the same object.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
